DataElement.preferredName: In Situ Hybridization DNA Probe Nucleotides Length Number
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The number that represents the length of the probe in nucleotides.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Use of a DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues_A piece of DNA that has been labeled, usually radioactively or with a fluorescent dye, which is used in hybridization studies.  Applications include Northern and Southern blots, in situ hybridization techniques, and diagnostic tests.  DNA probes can be highly specific or degenerate.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Use of a DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues

Concepts.definition: Use of a DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues.

Property.preferredDefinition: A piece of DNA that has been labeled, usually radioactively or with a fluorescent dye, which is used in hybridization studies.  Applications include Northern and Southern blots, in situ hybridization techniques, and diagnostic tests.  DNA probes can be highly specific or degenerate.

ValueDomain.preferredName: in situ Hybridization Probe Nucleotides Length Number

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: in situ Hybridization Probe Nucleotides Length Number
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Use of a DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues:General term for a piece of DNA or RNA corresponding to a gene or sequence of interest, that has been labelled either radioactively or with some other detectable molecule, such as biotin, digoxygenin or fluorescein. As stretches of DNA or RNA with complementary sequences will (hybridize), a probe will label viral plaques, bacterial colonies or bands on a gel that contain the gene of interest. (On-line Medical Dictionary):The monomeric units from which DNA or RNA polymers are constructed. They consist of a purine or pyrimidine base, a pentose sugar, and a phosphate group. (From King & Stansfield, A Dictionary of Genetics, 4th ed):Length; the linear extent in space from one end to the other.:Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.

Concepts.definition: Use of a DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues.

General term for a piece of DNA or RNA corresponding to a gene or sequence of interest, that has been labelled either radioactively or with some other detectable molecule, such as biotin, digoxygenin or fluorescein. As stretches of DNA or RNA with complementary sequences will hybridize, a probe will label viral plaques, bacterial colonies or bands on a gel that contain the gene of interest.

A subunit of DNA or RNA consisting of a nitrogenous base (adenine, guanine, thymine, or cytosine in DNA; adenine, guanine, uracil, or cytosine in RNA), a phosphate molecule, and a sugar molecule (deoxyribose in DNA and ribose in RNA).
The linear extent in space from one end of something to the other end, or the extent of something from beginning to end.
A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification.

ClassificationSchemes.longName: DCTD (Division of Cancer Treatment and Diagnosis)
